text: Matt: How much chicken manure is, is this?

Richardson: Umm...there’s probably 100 tons
in here.
Matt: That’s Lee Richardson.

He’s a farmer in Willards, Maryland, who
raises corn, soybeans, and, obviously, chickens.

You might notice that his chicken houses are
empty, though.

Richardson had just sent his birds to market,
so he was between flocks when we visited.
But we were actually there to see the manure.

All that chicken excrement left behind could
be a valuable asset...or a costly nuisance.

In either case, the reason boils down to one
element: Phosphorus.

Manure is a great natural fertilizer because
it’s got what plants crave: nitrogen, potassium,
and phosphorus.

Chicken manure is particularly rich in phosphorus,
actually too rich for Richardson.

And for many other farmers on the Delmarva
Peninsula, so named because it has parts of
Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia on it.
In 2016, Delmarva was home to 4,700 chicken houses, producing over 4 billion pounds of chicken.

That puts a lot of manure and phosphorus really
close to the Chesapeake Bay, which is cause
for concern.

Eighty percent of the bay’s phosphorus pollution
comes from agriculture, notably manure used
as fertilizer.

When rain washes nutrients from fertilizer
into bodies of water, the compounds fuel the
growth of algae and bacteria.
These algal blooms do all sorts of damage.

For example, they can poison the water and
deplete its oxygen, choking out aquatic ecosystems.

Algal blooms grow all over the world, but
let’s focus on the Chesapeake, a national

treasure according to Executive Order 13508,
signed by Barack Obama in 2009.

This executive order called on state governments
to help clean and protect the Chesapeake by,

among other things, reducing its phosphorus
content.

In June 2015, Maryland rolled out what’s
known as the Phosphorus Management Tool, or
PMT.

The PMT are rules limiting how much phosphorus
farmers can use based on how much is already
in their soil.

Roughly 20% of the farmland in Maryland exceeds
the PMT’s lower phosphorus threshold, meaning

those farmers will have to stop using manure
or start using less of it by 2022.

For Richardson, the PMT means he needs to
scale back or potentially cease his manure
usage in 2018.

So he’s going to have tons of manure he
can’t use.

He could give it away to farms with low levels
of phosphorus, but he doesn’t sound too
excited about that option.

Richardson: It’s going to be costly to transport
it 100, 150 miles.
And that may be what we’re looking at.
We won’t get anything for it.
It’d be zero dollars for us.

Matt: And he’s got reasons beyond money
to want to keep the chicken manure.

Richardson: The great thing is is manure just
doesn't contain phosphorus.
It's got a lot of minor elements.

It's got a lot of nitrogen; that's what we
want still.

Matt: So if there were some way to extract
the phosphorus from manure,

Richardson wouldn’t have to ship his manure
anywhere. And it’d be better for the bay.

And the concentrated, extracted phosphorus
would still be a valuable fertilizer, meaning

it could be sold for profit to other parts
of the country or world that need it.

As you may have guessed, we aren’t the first
people to put all this together.

Lee Blaney: So I was in my office one day
I got a phone call kind of out of the blue
from a company.

They said, "We're trying to recover nutrients from poultry
litter.”

And so I said, “Okay, well I definitely know
phosphorus chemistry and so let's start talking.”

And so I started talking had a couple of ideas
and then we developed what we call the Phosphorus
Extraction And Recovery System.
Or PEARS.
Matt: Just a quick note.
You heard Blaney call it poultry litter.

That’s the manure mixed with the bedding
from the chicken houses.

We visited Blaney’s lab near Baltimore to
learn how his team gets the phosphorus out
of that litter.

Hannah Aris: So here we have the raw poultry
litter that has been taken from farms.

Matt: I like that you can see there are feathers
in there.
Aris: Yeah, exactly.
Matt: That is definitely poultry litter.

Aris: Yes
Aris: So what we have to do is we put it through
a processor and it grinds it up.
And then we put it in a dryer and then we take that out, we get this.

Matt: Yes, that was a food processor, which
works great for the team’s lab-scale reactor.

To go to the farm, the team needs to scale
up their entire process.

Blaney believes the group will have that done
within the next five years.

So let’s take a look at the phosphorus-extracting
reactor itself, which is made of three separate
chambers.

In the first chamber, the team mixes dry chicken
litter with water.

They carefully measure the amounts of each
so they can account for all the mass in their
system and monitor how well it’s performing.

The system mixes the litter and water to form
a slurry.

Then it pumps the slurry into the second chamber,
called the extraction reactor chamber.

Here, the system bubbles the slurry with carbon
dioxide and adds a touch of hydrochloric acid.

This acidifies the slurry, lowering its pH
to liberate phosphorus and other elements
from the solid manure particles.

Next, the team waits for the solids to settle
out, which allows them to then pump the phosphorus-rich,
acidic liquid to the third chamber.

Here, sodium hydroxide flows in to raise the
pH to basic conditions, allowing phosphorus

to mineralize as struvite, or magnesium ammonium
phosphate.

The team can recover 70 to 80% of the phosphorus
from the manure as struvite, which can be
sold as fertilizer.

And the phosphorus is way more concentrated
in struvite than in manure, meaning the mineral

weighs much less and is much more economical
to transport.

What’s more, the team has also developed
a process to get potassium struvite instead
of struvite.

The two are similar, except potassium struvite
swaps in potassium for the nitrogen-containing
ammonium.

So processing chicken litter gives the team
access to potassium, nitrogen, and phosphorus.
That’s what plants crave.

Don’t forget, either, that’s there’s
still phosphorus-deficient manure in the reactor.

That means farmers can put that manure back
on their fields to take advantage of the leftover
nutrients without worrying about phosphorus.

And the PEARS process could work for more
than just chicken manure.

Blaney: Moving forward I think there's a lot
of issues coming out of some of the intensive
pig farms, as well.
In terms of both nitrogen and phosphorus issues.

We can definitely apply the PEARS chemistry
to that swine manure.

Matt: One of the things that stands out the
most when talking to Blaney is that he doesn’t

see waste as waste--he sees it as a resource
that can solve problems.

Blaney: Right now, most of the world's phosphorus
comes from one country: Morocco.

And so you can imagine that this is like a
big economic liability.

This is a big political liability. You know,
if Morocco shuts down their phosphorus exports,

how is the rest of the world going to grow
food?

Matt: While developing PEARS, Blaney’s team
paid attention to the cost and design of the

system to make sure they were building something
farmers would actually want to use.

Which is not to suggest farmers are averse
to technology.
Richardson actually started calling up people to inquire about phosphorus-extraction technology years

ago, when he first read about it in a trade
magazine.

And now he’s donating manure to Blaney’s
project to help it along.

And sure, he wants this technology to succeed
so he can continue using his manure.

But the fact that this could protect the Chesapeake
is not lost on him.
Richardson: We live here.
We raise our children here, you know.

This kind of situation would be a win-win
for us as well as the environment, you know.

So we're doing everything we can and hope
that science keeps progressing
that we can keep progressing.

Matt: One last fun fact about chicken litter:
It doesn’t stink as bad as you’d think
it would.
I mean, it’s not great.

It’s a sort of dank, earthy odor, but when
it’s just sitting out in the open,
it's not terrible.

And when the scientists scooped it in the
lab, it smelled almost exactly like a chocolate candy.

I won’t tell you which one, but there are
two Ms involved.
